comment_body.0:
Please help. After searching around for over a year and a half I'm kinda back at square one.

Location: Michigan
Price range: ~35-40k
Lease or Buy: Buy (I will drive this thing till the wheels fall off. Yes, I have attachment issues)
New or used: Either, but preferably New
Type of vehicle: Car/Sports Car
Must haves: Power(280hp+. Preferably 300+). Manual, or perhaps a really, really fun DCT). AWD or FWD for Michigan Winters. 4 Doors (sigh...kids are in the future)
Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual.
Intended use: Daily Driver/occasional weekend getaway vehicle for me and the wife.
Vehicles you've already considered: Subaru WRX/STI; 2022 Hyundai Elantra N (current choice); Dodge Charger(decided I didn't want to drive a boat but please feel free to change my mind if you own one); Ford Mustang w/ 5.0 V8.
Is this your 1st vehicle: No.
Do you need a Warranty: Eh, not really.
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes.
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Some. Can't pull an engine but I don't mind getting under a car to do my own work.
Additional Notes:
The biggest thing for me about cars is the theatre and experience. I want noise, power, rowing through gears, crackles and pops! Buuuuut I also know that in the next year or so my wife and I will likely have our first child, so we discussed it and agreed that we will very likely need a 4 door car. I'm not super jazzed about that but c'est la vie.

My current selection is the Elantra N but I'm not sure if it's enough power, but I guess I won't know until I drive it. My guess is that it certainly will be enough. Others I considered are the Subaru WRX/STI but I've moved away from that since the release of the newest model (I think it looks absolutely atrocious) and the fact that there just seems to be SO MUCH work that needs to go into an STI to get it to where I would want it to be.

I've even looked into buying an old Bentley Flying Spur(in my dreams) because I really want a super fun feeling. I like smaller cars and my current DD is a 2000 Toyota Celica GT. I love that car and high revving engines, but it just doesn't fit my needs anymore.

Thanks in advance for your help, suggestions, insults, and more.

comment_body.2:
Like everyone else, we are in need of a car at the worst possible moment. But here we are.

Our situation:

We are a family of 4, in the Chicago area. Two young kids still in car seats.

We have a Subaru Impreza hatchback which we love, but it’s small. And we now need a second car. The Subaru will be for one adult to commute to work. The new car will be for moving kids, larger shopping trips, going camping, road trips, etc.

We ideally want to buy a car that we’ll have for a while.

We’ve been looking at Toyota Highlanders. They seem to meet that sweet spot where they have off-road capability, Japanese reliability, not obscenely huge, but something our family can grow into.

Budget is pretty much whatever we want it to be, but ideally around $30k. We also don’t want to throw money at a car. We just want it to move us around in relative comfort, drive through snow and mud, fit a growing family, and last a while. We camp a lot and want something we can travel in.

We don’t care much about trim. We take good care of our things, but we don’t need or want high-end.

We’re looking at both used and new, and simply can’t decide what makes the most sense in these current conditions.

Thank you for any advice. Please feel free to ask follow-ups.
comment_body.3:
I find myself at a crossroads. My truck, a 2012 F150, crossed over 120k miles recently, heading quickly for the age of heavy repairs to stay on the road. And fuck me am I sick of 14mpg with that 5.0 V8. So.

Located in the US PNW

Price range...sub $40k, I think. Lower is better but I'm not gonna be sacrificing comfort or capability for the sake of my wallet, y'know? Looks like I'll be able to rack up $15k+ for my trade in cuz dealers around here are desperate for trucks.

Buying, New.

Type...this is where I'm unsure. I've always been a truck guy, but I've moved into a denser city now, don't do much towing or farm work anymore, so I'm not certain I can justify it anymore.

Must haves: 4x4/AWD at a minimum, I'm no hardcore rock-crawler but I regularly run some pretty messed up forest roads. I'm looking to increase my fuel efficiency for sure.

Auto preferred, never drove stick

Intended use: I'm lucky enough to commute on foot so this will be a weekend warrior, road trips so rider/driver comfort is important, camping/hunting so off-road ability and a dirt-proof cargo space equally important.

Vehicles I've considered: Maverick is tempting but I'm not sure about comfort at that cabin size, Subarus lineup of course, all the trucks except the Ridgeline though I'm not a big Toyota fan.

Not my first rodeo

Warranties would be nice

I can do my own maintenance, but major mechanic work goes to the shop.

Additional notes: This is my current ride. I'm used to being able to go wherever I want without much concern with whether or not I'll be able to survive the trip. I hunt, hike, camp, love long road trips, do some minor wheeling just for the sake of mud, and I go target shooting deep in the woods. When my rig goes out we come back dirty. I don't want to change that, but I would really like to not spend $80 every weekend to fill the tank. I don't need towing, I just want to be able to drive to Alaska in winter and bring back a bloody elk carcass on a whim, without destroying the environment along the way. I would love a hybrid or electric.

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Some

Additional Notes: My 02 Mustang has bit the dust. My next car needs to be more practical (4 doors) and fairly comfortable, but I still want it to be fun to drive. The upcoming Elantra N seems ideal to me. Same with the GR Corolla. Not sure if I can wait long enough to buy either, though. I could opt for a GTI, but I'm not sure if the 2022 models are at dealerships yet. Similar story with the WRX: If the upcoming redesign is more comfortable with a nicer interior than the old one, I'll definitely put it on the list, but I may not be able to wait that long. The Civic Type R and Veloster N are both great, but the former is too pricey and the latter is too small. If I decided to ditch the manual-transmission, fun-to-drive side of things, I'd just get an Accord Sport 2.0T and call it "good enough."

(Posted this on Sunday right before last week's thread went away, figured I'd try again!)

comment_body.14:
Location: Southern California

Price range: $30k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Sports Car

Must haves: Lightweight, good inputs (steering, clutch feel, shifter), reliability, ideally reasonably low cost of ownership.

Desired transmission: Prefer manual, but not opposed to a good auto.

Intended use: Weekend Car

Vehicles you've already considered: FR-S, S2000, Miata

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Can do suspension work, can't do anything else.

Additional Notes: Loved the Integra Type R back in the day, picked up the FR-S when it was new because I was hoping it would be roughly the equivalent of a RWD ITR. Loved the FR-S overall - had great steering, a good clutch, and good shifter feel - but wanted something without the torque dip without having to mess with CARB legality.

Ended up selling the FR-S for $18k with 30k miles on the clock because I also own an Insight, and it didn't think it made sense to have a "compromise" sports car when I don't drive much anymore due to WFH. Tried out an S2K since it's philosophically similar to the FR-S but with less compromise, but the only clean examples I found are $30k+ and this might be blasphemous to say, but the S2K isn't $15k better (after taxes/fees) than the FR-S. Engine's better, but steering feel is worse, and clutch/shifter feel are roughly equal.

So, my question is, are there any other fun, lightweight, cars that I'm missing? I don't and have never really loved the Miata, which I think is the other primary contender in this category. At this point, I'm thinking my best bet may be to just wait a couple of years until the second gen BRZ/GR86 begin to hit the used market. Used GR Supra maybe down the line? I don't know, open to options.

comment_body.21:
Okay guys I found 2 cars in my area. having trouble deciding which one I should get. I live in the northeast, snow is a factor. I also have 3 children under age 10. Really wanted something sporty , awd, and 4 doors. I should also note that its mostly for running errands and pleasure driving. I have a company vehicle for commuting.

2017 Dodge charger sxt ralleye. YELLOW! Fully loaded. 57k miles. automatic $29k I test drove this car and it all around feels like a nicer car than the wrx. nicer interior better ride. not as sporty but more room. I would buy this if I had my choice but I really feel like its a lot of money for a car with 57k miles and im worried about potential resale down the road. I think I will lose my ass.

https://www.goldsteinchryslerdodgejeep.com/used-Albany-2017-Dodge-Charger-SXT-2C3CDXJG1HH516188

2019 wrx premium. 25k miles. $31k, 5 speed (this is a plus in my eyes) Pretty nice but overall less bells and whistles than the charger. Smaller car overall the kids will probably be a bit more cramped but they will get over it. I think its a bit quicker and will hold its value better but like I stated I dont think its as nice of a car. It is a pretty rough ride

https://www.carbonesubaruoftroy.com/used/Subaru/2019-Subaru-WRX-for-sale-Troy-NY-41f58c310a0e09b00028b8f176a15823.htm

My dad said they both suck dont buy either haha.

I know they are 2 very different cars but I really like both of them and having trouble deciding so ive turned to the reddit gods to help me decide. Thank you in advance for any opinions.

comment_body.28:
Looking at plug in hybrids. I have a new family and our 2009 civic is lacking cargo space.

What are peoples thoughts about leasing vs buying used?

My primary choice is a 2022 hyundai tucson phev (waiting list à few months).But at over $500 CAD a month for a 4 year lease its a heavy lift.

For the same monthly outlay I could finance a $20k to 25k vehicle such as a Honda Clarity, hyundai ioniq or mitsubishi outlander phev and have an asset at the end of the same 4 years. But I don't love any of those cars.

Plan C is to get a smaller 2021 hyundai ioniq plugin for $400 a month. Still bigger and more plactical than our civic (whose rear seats don't fold, I didn't even know that was possible)
comment_body.29:
Hyundai Tucson 1.6 T-GDI 180 HP or Hyundai Kona N 2.0 T-GDI 280 HP?

I have that dilemma, I can afford either one of those (new), but I'm not sure which one to pick. I'm in my early 30's and currently drive i30 1.4CRDI and it was a wonderful car for what I needed, but now I got bored because I'm missing the thrill of some decent acceleration and speed.

So I would choose Kona, but since my GF likes to travel a lot, maybe a Tucson could be a good compromise (More interior space, better off-road, lower fuel consumption and still decent performance).

So my question boils down to this: Would 180 HP SUV feel fun enough to drive for me, or should I take the 280 HP Kona, and accept it's a smaller car, and forget about off-roading?

Additional Notes: Looking to trade in my ram 1500 while used prices are good and get something smaller and brand new. I've bought a place in the city now, never really need a truck and dread getting in and out of my downtown parking every day for work. Something that has a bit of go would be nice, I haven't test driven anything but mainly looking at rav4s or bronco sport and it doesnt sound like they're too thrilling to drive and might feel like a big downgrade from a truck. That may be asking too much for my price point so I'm trying to manage expectations. Interior of my truck is pretty barebones so anything will be an upgrade from that.

I'm not sure how I feel about the rav4 hybrid engine, haven't looked into it too much yet tbh but not sure how it will do in -40 or long road trips. I do like the storage space and it looks like i (6'4") could sleep in the back with the seat down.

I've considered cars and from what I've seen I could get better performance and interior in my budget but I feel like that's a big change from a truck, very little storage and ground clearance concerns me. Maybe a nice hatchback could win me over.

Hi guys. I may be in the market soon for a new car; not out of desire but out of necessity. I currently have a 2014 Kia soul with 160k miles that's burning oil and I've been told it's just a matter of time before either the exhaust or engine needs some major repairs. Anyway, here's the deal:

​

Location: Orlando, FL

comment_body.45:
So I currently drive a 2003 Infinity QX4 (automatic), and a 2001 Miata (maual). I love the Miata more than anything, but hate my QX4. I want to sell it and get a better daily, so I can work on the Miata and leave it on jackstands for weeks and still get to and from work.

The predicament I'm in is whether to look for an auto or manual daily. I want a fun sporty sedan from the 90s-early 2000s, and as a car guy, I have a long list of dream sedans I would love to have that fit these needs. e36, e46, e30, Mazdaspeed Protege, Civic, Camry, etc, the list goes on.

I love the Miata and have dailyed it at times, and it wasn't too bad, i enjoy driving and having fun getting through traffic and I have a decently twisty commute to work. However, I live with my girlfriend (who can drive stick around the parking lot), but she wouldn't drive my car on the streets, as she is not comfortable driving stick, and doesn't really care to get better. This means if I ever borrow her car, she can't borrow either of mine. This, along with the fact that in the long run, I'll probably get sick of the manual at times (longer road trips, late at night when I'm tired, after leg day at the gym, etc.), and if I really want to have a fun drive, I have the Miata to take.

The QX4 works great being an auto, but I feel like if i got a sedan I really like and put some subtle mods (coilovers, wheels, and the such), I'd be like "Damn if only this were manual." It would just feel so wasteful getting a car I've been dreaming of, just to get it in automatic, but the perks of automatic entice me.
comment_body.46:

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No.

Additional Notes:

  1. ​price range is a bit flexible.
  2. Need enough storage space to fit my dog's crate on road trips (he gets car sick)
  3. AWD is not a MUST HAVE, but is definitely a Nice To Have.
  4. Speed/Hybrid/Electric are not all three required, but it must have one of the three. (My current car, a 2016 Subaru Outback, goes 0-60 in about 12 seconds and that's gotten a bit old)
  5. I can drive a manual, but I don't think there are many being made in the medium size at this point, and I prefer manual anyways.
  6. "Light towing" means "I might buy a teardrop trailer and take the dogs camping some time some day".
  7. Mazda CX-5 was fun to drive, but it didn't quite have enough zing to make it worth the price
  8. I liked the idea of the Maverick, but the dealership I asked said ordering now would probably put it about 9 months out to delivery, which is just a bit too far.
  9. I used to drive an F-150, but it was just too big to be fun to drive, which is why the Maverick appealed to me.

comment_body.52:
Location: SLC, Ut

Price range: Max $10k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: I love the idea of a luxury/sports sedan but pretty much anything is on the table. I really don’t care for SUVs or crossovers but I’m sure the right one could sway me

Must haves: Reliability has to be priority #1 but I would love something with nice driving dynamics and a little bit of lower-end torque for city driving

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual preferred but not mandatory. I would rather get something a little sporty with an auto than a boring stick

Intended use: Daily + Weekend fun car

Vehicles you've already considered: miata, infiniti g35/37, volvo s60, ford taurus, subaru wrx, mini cooper

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Super basic things like battery and oil are manageable but I have very little in the way of tools and know-how

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: Currently driving a turbo’d ‘94 miata and love it to death. Would absolutely drive it to the grave but the cost of maintaining a modded vehicle are proving to be steeper than I can accommodate. The original owner got forged rods and pins, turbo, AEM series 2 ecu, suspension, clutch, exhaust all aftermarket and I’m sure a few others things I’m forgetting but it ended up sitting in a shed for almost a decade. Been getting it back into shape and dailying it over the last 2 years but I think I have to accept the fact that paying a shop for diagnostics, parts and labor on a modded vehicle everytime something rusts out isn’t sustainable.

I know nothing in my price range is going to compete with this car, especially with the markets as they are but I have to get something with at least a little bit of fun factor that I can in good conscience show my wife to make it easier to let go of my current car. We’re considering selling mine now while the market is crazy and waiting a few months to see if it cools down at all, should we have any reason to believe used cars are going to be closer to sane prices in 6 months?

Tangential, but I also need help pricing the miata lol. Only found 2 working turbo’d ones for sale on a nationwide craigslist search and they were like $12k. Mine is in worse shape cosmetically and mechanically (huge dent behind driver side door, spews oil etc) but only 74k miles

I think we might live in a PHEV world in 3 to 5 years, so a lease is attractive for now, plus, I could cheaply lease something like a CX-30 for 3 years and ditch it before all the subscriptions kick in. Or I could buy something like the Trailhawk or Subaru that really hold their value decently well out here.

New or used: In this market, leaning towards new since I can wait for it to come in and used is tending to be highly expensive anyway (or unavailable)

Type of vehicle: Car, small SUV, or crossover. Nothing bigger than a Cherokee KL, for example

Must haves: AWD or 4x4, space for a kid carseat, PWR of 1:18 or better preferably, 25+mpg, some amount of ground clearance, android auto / carplay, relatively quiet ride, adaptive cruise control, prefer some premium sound system, decent reliability as I already have a project carDesired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Either is fine

Intended use: 90% commuting and visiting family on roads that are cracked and badly paved but have 75+mph speed limits but also have traffic jams in high heat and bitter cold sometimes. Merge ramps onto highways can take you from a stop to 70mph in a quarter mile. Also needs to be capable of getting up into the snowy or dirt road mountain roads occasionally (and out of a snowed in subdivision).

Vehicles you've already considered: Mostly looking at the Cherokee Trailhawk, Subaru Legacy Touring XT (ventilated seats are a nice bonus), Subaru WRX Premium, and the Mazda CX-30 Turbo Premium

Is this your 1st vehicle: Not remotely

Do you need a Warranty: Not particularly, but new, so ...

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Absolutely

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Yep, but would prefer less breakage on this car

Additional Notes: Considered the Bronco Sport Badlands, but had a ton of road noise and a high sticker price with bad gas mileage. The Rav4 Prime might be awesome, but it's impossible to get. The Mazda CX-5 is an option, but felt a bit like a minivan compared to the CX-30. Hyundai Kona N Line was kind of cool but dear got the absolute slowness from a stop was a deal breaker (brilliant once you were doing more than 5mph).

​

Also interested in opinions on the cars I'm mostly considering ... one vs the other or why not to get one or the other.
